key_title: Key to the species of Hypericum

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Elatinaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Elatinaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves no more than 3.5 cm long; herbs, rarely subshrubs
At least the largest leaves usually 4 cm long or more; shrubs or subshrubs, rarely herbs
Plants without black gland-dots; mostly native species
Black gland-dots present on petals and anthers (and often also leaves, stems, and/or sepals); naturalized aliens
Shrubs, more than 1 m high at maturity; petals more than 1 cm long; weed from far north-west Victoria
Herbs under 0.5 m; petals to c. 8 mm long; widespread native species

Stems erect; leaves ovate to narrowly elliptic, at least the uppermost stem-clasping, margins usually recurved; flowers in leafy cymes; pedicels generally longer than subtending leaves; mature capsule usually exceeding sepals

Stems prostrate or procumbent; leaves elliptic to obovate, spreading from stems, margins not recurved (but often undulate); flowers often solitary; pedicels shorter than subtending leaves; mature capsule no longer than sepals
Sepals with black gland-dots; stems procumbent or erect
Sepals without black gland-dots; stems erect or ascending
Stems procumbent, internodes with 2 weakly developed ridges; sepals obtuse
Stems erect, internodes with 4 narrow wings; sepals acute
Stem internodes with 4 narrow wings
Stem internodes not 4-winged
Leaves conspicuously dotted by translucent glands, margins recurved; stem internodes distinctly 2-ridged; widespread weed
Leaves not conspicuously dotted by translucent or transparent glands, margins undulate but not recurved; stem internodes hardly ridged; apparently Dunolly area only
Procumbent, rhizomatous plant; flower solitary; styles 5; anthers reddish
Erect, shrubby plants; flowers in terminal cymes; styles 3; anthers yellow
Shrubs to 4 m high; leaves narrow-elliptic to somewhat oblong, ±  cuneate at base; petals persistent
Shrubs to 1 m, rarely to 2 m high; leaves oblong to broadly elliptic, rounded or cordate at base; petals soon deciduous
Petals shorter than or slightly longer than sepals; ripe fruit black; leaves strongly discolorous, more or less curry-scented
Petals c. twice as long as sepals; ripe fruit reddish; leaves ± concolorous, minutely reticulate-patterned beneath, not curry-scented
Petals 3–4 times as long as sepals; outer sepals oblong or narrowly elliptic; fruit completely dehiscent
Petals up to twice as long as sepals; outer sepals broadly ovate; fruit not or incompletely dehiscent
